title: EE Electrical TENTACLE PROBES - for EE and Arduino Cabinet

description.text:
These are Tentacle Wire Probes for Breadboards.

I tried another version, but they took a long time to print , and I had a hard time trying to link them.
These took a minute or 2 to print each chain link - and connect easily.

I mounted these on the EE Breadboard Cabinet Panel.
They can be used to hold delicate Parts ,
or supply a Voltage ,
or connect to an LED to measure a state ,
or connect to a Meter.

They have internal Holes to allow Wire(s) to feed through the Tentacle Probe.

author: pghhgp

description.text: Students in a second grade class were learning about animals and the habitats in which they live. During this project students used TinkerCAD to create a habitat for an animal of their choice. Their habitat had to be in a certain geographic location and provide food, water, and shelter for their animal to live.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Mapping the results

After printing the students placed their habitats on a map that showed where their ecosystems were located.

TinkerCAD

Students designed their habitats on TinkerCAD. Before this lesson please ensure that each student has a TinkerCAD log in to begin their creations. Because we printed one per student we shrank down the models and placed multiple on a build plate at a time.

Students learned all about different ecosystems around the world and what animals live there. Students learned about the shelters that animals make, the food they eat, and how they get their water in different types of environments. Students were asked to use TinkerCAD to create a habitat suitable for an animal that lives in an ecosystem of their choosing. The habitat must include shelter and a food source! Objectives Students should be able to identify the different types of environments in which animals live: Desert, Tundra, Rainforest, Ocean, Savannah, Forest. Once they choose the environment they want to create in TinkerCAD the students must create a habitat for an animal that lives there including features of the environment, the animal’s shelter, a food source, and water source. Audience This project was done with second graders but could be done with any elementary grade 2-6. Subjects This lesson accompanied a science lesson where students learned about animals, habitats, and animal needs for survival. It also included social studies information when talking about environment and where these different landforms are found on a map. After the students created their habitats the teacher used the completed 3D prints with an activity in which students actually had to locate where the environment could be found on a map. This lesson can also tie into language arts. Students were asked to write about their animal and the habitat they built for it. They had to explain their habitat and show how an animal would successfully life in the habitat with the food, water, and shelter source. Skills Learned (Standards) Virginia SOL: SCI 2.5b: The student will investigate and understand that living things are part of a system. Key concepts include:
a) living organisms are interdependent with their living and nonliving surroundings; and
b) habitats change over time due to many influences.
Common Core Standards: 3.2a Individuals within a species may compete with each other for food, mates, space,
water, and shelter in their environment http://www.p12.nysed.gov/ciai/mst/pub/elecoresci.pdf

• In class students learn about different environments and the animal habitats found there.
  • Students learn about what animals need to survive: food, water, shelter
  • Students are given the chance to choose which environment they want to create in TinkerCAD: Desert, Tundra, Rainforest, Ocean, Savannah, Forest.
  • Once students have chosen their environment they need to choose an animal that lives in that habitat in order to model its best environment.
  • Then students create a drawn draft of what they want to create. Students need to make sure their habitat includes a feature of the environment, food, water, and shelter for their animal.
  • After the student’s draft is approved by the teacher they may begin working in TinkerCAD.
  • Students log into TinkerCAD and begin creating their model of the habitat they chose.
  • Once students finish the teacher needs to ensure that the creation has all of the components and is ready for printing.
    • Forest Habitat Tundra Habitat Tips and Tricks Before printing it's important to go through each student's design to ensure that their creations are printable. For example: We often had student's who created awesome trees however the treetops often "floated" above the tree trunks instead of actually being connected. Doing a quick check that objects are correctly layered and designed will help immensely when it comes down to printing. We also printed multiple habitats on a build plate at a time. It cut down on printing time and allowed the printer to run all day instead of shorter prints that needed to constantly be started throughout the day. Also, before printing we created a base layer, or "floor" aspect of each habitat. We went through and made a thin layer on the bottom of each habitat to ensure that the whole design was printed in one solid piece instead of printing the habitat, trees, water source, etc. as all little separate pieces.
After students learned about the habitats unit in class the actual 3D modeling and creating part took the students two 30-minute computer lab times.

Before beginning in TinkerCAD students need to understand what the different environments (Desert, Tundra, Rainforest, Ocean, Savannah, Forest) look like.  They need to understand how the different environments effect the animals that live there.  Students also need to understand that animals need food, water, and shelter to survive.
Please see the attached PDF of a written assessment.
https://educators.brainpop.com/lesson-plan/comparing-rainforest-desert-and-freshwater-habitats-lesson-plan/

A remix, or total do over of my hinged 10 dollars worth of quarters. One of the comments on my hinged box design asks, why didn't I make it cylindrical? So I did!  
I've actually moved all my quarters to these containers now instead of the hinged containers. These cylinders don't stack nicely in my desk drawer, so I just stand them up as you see in the picture.  
Threaded cap prints with plenty of tolerance so don't worry about it not fitting. It'll fit and it will cinch up nice and tight with a 3/4 turn.

comments.text: I get a warning when trying to export the gcode from Slic3r.  Apparently there is a hole in the triangulated mesh somewhere.  I'm using Slic3r v0.9.10b.

comments.text: This was modeled in Solidworks, which is very good at producing models with no holes or errors. The STL slices perfectly on Makerware, and prints without issue. It's most likely that Slic3r is choking on the extremely thin wall at the top of the cylinder. It's thin, but there's no holes in it. Maybe try less shells when you slice it, use another slicer or see if Meshlab Cloud will fix it for you.

title: BCN3D Sigma E3D v6 Hotend Mount

description.text: This is a E3D v6 hotend mount for the BCN3D Sigma. I still need to supply proper instructions so plear bear with me! :)

Parts Required

E3D v6 Hotends

2 of these http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6/Full-Kit?product_id=382

Connectors

Please be aware that the E3D v6 hotends will not have the correct connectors. It's up to you to modify as needed. The connectors used for the Sigma are as follows:

Hotend

UK
http://uk.farnell.com/jst-japan-solderless-terminals/pap-04v-s/housing-crimp-receptacle-2mm-4way/dp/1830729
http://uk.farnell.com/jst-japan-solderless-terminals/sphd-002t-p0-5/crimp-socket-24-28awg/dp/1830725

USA
http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/jst-sales-america-inc/PAP-04V-S/455-1488-ND/759976
http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/jst-sales-america-inc/SPHD-002T-P0.5/455-1313-1-ND/608809

Fans (You don't need these. Just for reference, You can use the stock fans)

UK
http://uk.farnell.com/jst-japan-solderless-terminals/phr-2/housing-2way-2mm/dp/3616186
http://uk.farnell.com/jst-japan-solderless-terminals/bph-002t-p0-5s/contact-loose-piece-0-05-0-22mm/dp/3617210

Nuts & Bolts (Total for both extruders)

  • 4x 30MM hex head M3 bolts (To hold the front & back plate)
  • 8x 25mm dome/button hex M3 bolts (To hold the layer fan)
  • 4x 6MM dome/button hex M3 bolts (to hold the layer fan tray)
  • 8x 16MM dome/button hex M3 bolts (to hold the hotend fan)
  • 8x M3 nyloc nuts (to hold the hotend fan)

It's now up to you to put this together. Detailed instructions will follow, i promise.

Printing
  • You should print at a 0.1 layer height to get any of the threads correct.
  • The back plate should use 85% infill and the other parts should use 50% infill
  • Only use support for the layer fan tray

2016/08/10
- Added pictures of the nuts & bolts and connectors to the description
- Updated the links to USA suppliers of the connectors thanks to freddotu

title: The B3 - Wrongman v.1.0 (Titanfall Inspired Handgun Prop)

description.text:
I can't believe i have to say this but just in case....THIS IS NOT A REAL GUN.

Titanfall 2 is coming out soon(ish) and i pre ordered the 'super mega deluxe give me all your money epic win' edition that comes with the 1:1 scale pilots helmet. Figured alot of people are going to use this helmet for cosplay and every pilot needs a weapon right?

So i designed the the B3 - Wrongman, which is heavily inspired by the B3 - Wingman from the game. I've always wanted to print a prop gun but my printer (m3d micro) has a print bed the size of a stamp so i made this guy in segments, some of which plug into eachother to make it easy to line them up. Everything else you just superglue. The segments also make it alot easier to paint...i imagine? i have no idea. i suck at painting.

This is the first version so if any of you have any constructive feedback i'm happy to update the model over time :) It's not a perfect replica but it will certainly do the job.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Dealers Choice

Infill:

None

Notes:

I printed all the parts hollow with the thick walls setting enabled in the M3D software. It's pretty light in weight when assembled. I used rafts on everything except the trigger but thats just because i forgot to.

The M3D software automatically adds supports to models that it knows it cant print without them so for your information the parts that will need supports are as follows:

  • Barrel 2
  • Hammer Housing
  • Flashlight

Assembly

1.Print all the parts

  1. Sand off scrap material (i have some tiny files, they work great)
  2. superglue the hell out of everything.
  3. bask in the glow of your new B3 - Wrongman

What i gone and did.

There really wasn't much resource material to go by. i found a side on image on google and basically just used that as a reference. I improvised all the 3 dimensional parts and ran test prints to see how they fit together until everything just looked right.

These pendants are based on an irregular 15 sided polygon composed of a pentagon, five squares, and twenty rhombs. One is a portion of a pattern that tiles the plane and comes from Kevin Jardine's Imperfect Congruence site - http://gruze.org/tilings/globe - where it is called the globe "jewel". The second is a variation which has a 5 fold rotation axis. The construction is the same as that used for thing:163043, Multicolored Pendants. Stl files for the bases and inserts are provided along with the openSCAD code that created them. Stl files are: globe_jewel_base.stl and 5_fold_base.stl - the two bases for inserts and 5 files of inserts - pentagon.stl, square.stl, 5-rhomb.stl, 10-rhomb.stl and 20-rhomb.stl.

All files are best printed directly on the build platform.  
As with thing:163043, Multicolored Pendants, a tiny spot of adhesive is placed in a recess and the insert pressed into place.  
The globe "jewel" pendant differs from the version in Jardine's tiling for convenience in construction.  The edge lengths of the polygons are not uniform and some of the rhombs have been altered to better fit the recesses.  The inserts are not suitable for tiling.  
The full globe tiling includes 20 sided polygons.  A portion of the full tiling is shown in the image at the right above.  It was constructed by placing tiles on a piece of black felt.  The tiles are a set of polygons with uniform edge length.  The openSCAD code that was used to generate the tiles is globe_tiles.scad and is included.  
The image shows how the globe "jewel" fits into the overall tiling.  Four "jewels" occur in mirrored pairs which share 3 rhombs.

description.text:
Hello,

I did the same job as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:854608
but I have a dual head, so now one is direct an the other is bowden.

I did not change the hot end only modified one of the two hotend plastic part by drilling the top @ 4mm and then use PTFE directly, with exactly thhe same principal.

I used the already existing extruder parts but the right extruder (upside down).

Doing so and using the wiring of hotend 2 in hotend 1 no need to tweek the Firrmware stuff to reverse the rotation.

Hope it helped ...

author: Omegh

description.text:
A fairly parametric revolver cylinder has numbshots = 6;
revradius = 35;
dartsize = 10; available. numbshots determines how many rounds it can fit, revradius determines how wide the cylander is and dartsize determines how big the darts for it are.
This filament guide will also clean the filament on its way to your extruder.

Print it with a decent infill, I suggest 60%. You will need an extra:
  • 4 T slot nuts
  • 4 washers
  • 4 M5x10 bolts
  • Bits of sponge
    • Cut the sponge a little bit too big, I have put in two pieces of sponge to leave a "gap" for the filament. If you make it too big, it will rub nicely along the filament for extra cleanlyness :)

author: Coalminer

print_settings.Notes:: For purposes of this project, any settings are appropriate as the main focus is to allow students to measure the effects of different temperatures on particular shapes using ABS or PLA plastic.

title: Testing Different Temperatures with 3D Prints: Thermodynamics Project

description.text:
Project #7 - Effects of Temperature on 3D Prints

While it is known by 3D printing enthusiasts about the need for printing at appropriate temperatures for different materials when printing, this knowledge should be put to the test in a classroom setting in which students can evaluate the effects of three different temperature settings on a particular 3D printed object.

Printer:

Flashforge 3D Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.27

Infill:

10%

Notes:

For purposes of this project, any settings are appropriate as the main focus is to allow students to measure the effects of different temperatures on particular shapes using ABS or PLA plastic.

**NOT THE SPECIFIED PRINT IN THIS PROJECT** An easy way to keep track of print temperatures to ensure accuracy in printing is to remove the hood and use the thermal sensor (ie: Thermal Sensor Gun) over different time intervals to ensure temperature consistency.
Any type of object can be printed for this project to test the effects of different temperatures on 3D prints. This object was designed on SketchUp.
NGSS

Students in a physics/physical science/chemistry settings can explore the structural effects of different temperatures in the context of 3D printing. Knowing temperatures can affect the way the plastic melts through the extrusion nozzles, teachers can specify particular temperatures they would like students to test on a particular object, By creating a chart and comparing different temperatures to printing results, a classroom can arrive at a better understanding of not only thermodynamics, but also about 3D printing. See attached handout for a sample lab assignment Objectives Students will be using an infrared temperature sensor to ensure that 3D printing temperatures for the 3D printer being used for the prints are consistent. Students will be evaluating the differences in structural integrity and form for a specific 3D printed object that is printed at different temperatures (200C, 220C, 240*C) Audiences Grades (7-12)
Ages (12-18)
Skill Levels (all) Subjects Science, Physics, Physical Science, Chemistry, Intro. to Engineering Skills Learned (Standards) HS-PS1-5. Apply scientific principles and evidence to provide an explanation about the effects of changing the temperature or concentration of the reacting particles on the rate at which a reaction occurs.

Teacher will need to create groups of at 2 students (up to 6) and also have enough 3D printers to have these groups surround them to conduct the lab. Each printer should have its own handheld thermal IR sensor gun
  • Split up groups to designated 3D printers
  • Have students wait for you (the instructor) to start the first set of prints at 200*C
  • Have students observe and write down notes about the print quality and overall structural integrity of the print (ie: working/not working, layers are binding, filament looks burnt, etc.)
  • Test heat consistency of the 3D printing environment with the sensor gun periodically (every 3 minutes)
  • Allow print to cool before removing and evaluating it for overall quality.
  • Repeat steps 2-5 for the same print at 220C and 240C
  • Finalize all recorded data and sit down quietly at desks when finished.
  • Share data and debrief lab activity with the class.

handheld thermal IR sensor guns (one per group)
enough 3D printers so that at least 4 groups can observe/record effects of a print at a designated temperature
*large enough lab space for groups of students to stand around the printers
• HS-PS1-5
2 hour lab.  -15 minutes to brief students on lab assignment -1.5 hours to record data and conduct observations -30 minutes to debrief lab and share data

http://www.nextgenscience.org/dci-arrangement/hs-ps1-matter-and-its-interactions - Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) https://filaments.ca/pages/temperature-guide - large table of relevant printing temperatures for different 3D printing materials Rubric & Assessment See attached rubric. No assessment required. Handouts & Assets See attached worksheet for the lab assignment.

title: Longboard Orangatang Kegel 38 Tooth Lock Nut Pulley for 9mm, 12mm, 15mm Belt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
28/08/2016: Updated file for better fit against the core

If you're into building and talking about esk8s then come pay us a visit: http://www.electric-skateboard.builders/

This file has cut outs for the nuts that correspond to 10-24 or 10-32 bolts. Both nuts have the same outer dimensions and so will work with this file. The pulley has clearance holes to allow for the bolt to pass right through and engage the lock nut. A 2 inch bolt will be long enough to engage the nylon locking ring in a lock nut. To insert the nuts, thread them on backwards to the bolt and using the wheel as support, push them down into the cut outs from the backside of the pulley. Once seated, unthread the bolt and the nuts will remain in place.

The minimum clearance required for use is 21mm diameter so will hit Caliber II trucks and probably Caliber I trucks, Paris should be fine as well as other round profile trucks.
The pictures show a Caliber II truck and the one that's highlighted in blue shows what you have to file off to use this with them.

There's a "21"mm clearance file as well which you can print and slide over the axle to check/mark what you need to file off. The file is actually 19mm diameter because 21 mm is a very tight fit but theoretically it would work but you can scale it to whatever you'd like.

After printing, you may just want to take a 3/16th Drill bit and clear out the holes for the bolts if you have any debris in them.

I've printed one file to confirm fitment, no issues on this print so enjoy!

Mounting hardware:

5X 10-32X2.00" Bolt (or 10-24)
5X 10-32 Lock Nut (or 10-24)
Alt: 5X 10-32 Nut (or 10-24) +Loctite Thread Locker if you don't have access to lock nuts.
5X #10 Washer (optional, to be placed between bolt head and Orangatang Kegel Flat Face Adapter)

There is tons of work that went into making these and the other pulley series on here so if you wish to contribute feel free to donate any amount you wish.

print_settings.Notes:: You can use resolution 0.2 if you want. It won't matter that much to have a coarser resolution, it's just a matter of personal preference.

description.text:
When designing new objects which will be printed on my 3D printer I am frequently needing to know what size hole I need to put into the design. For example I can't just assume that an M3 bolt needs a 3mm hole - doing so will produce a printed object where the M3 bolt simply won't go through that hole!

I am also regularly faced with requiring 2 different sizes of hole. First, I want a clearance fit where the bolt will slide through the hole unimpeded. Other times I'm looking for a hole which will grip the item being located by that hole. For example, for a bolt I want a hole with a clearance fit. However if I want to use a nutsert (sometimes called a rivnut) then I want the hole containing the nutsert to tightly hold the nutsert.

finding the correct sized holes can be a challenge involving repeated printing until I discover the right size hole. This challenge can be further complicated by using a different material - switching PLA for ABS or nylon can produce different results.

The answer to this challenge is to print the hole jigs contained in this project. Just once using the material you will be using. Then you've got a handy jig containing holes which you can pass your bolts etc through to find the right size. No more fiddling around trying to guess the sizes required - you get the required size instantly.

The attached STL files cover the range between 3mm and 25mm. For 3-9.9mm the holes increment by 0.1mm. For 10mm and above the holes increase by 0.2mm - you probably won't need anything with a closer tolerance than this.

Incidentally, the plates on which the holes are located are all 2mm thick, and the lettering sits on top. If you've got a smart printing application (such as Simplify3D), with a multi-extruder printer you can change the extruder colour at 2mm so that the legends shown on the jigs are printed in a different colour.

Enjoy!

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

No

0.1

Infill:

20%

You can use resolution 0.2 if you want. It won't matter that much to have a coarser resolution, it's just a matter of personal preference.

title: Printrbot Metal Simple Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
Minimalist filament holder for the Printrbot Metal Simple that works with 2.75" wide spools (standard).

I needed a long fan duct for my delta. My hot-end is mounted fairly high which doesn't leave much room for the fan. I couldn't find anything that worked well for me so I designed my own. Pardon the appearance of the parts, I printed this in sopping wet nylon. Although ugly, it works remarkably well.

If you print it, you can decide how many links you need for your particular set up. You can also make your own custom version from the On-Shape files, https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d048366c31a8780dc5d50f0f/w/acbbb8080b99b8b1bc5c9a48/e/2fdd3e67b086bacbf7427f40. In particular you can easily customize the length of the nozzle.

It is designed for the typical AV-5015 blower fans.
As shown, it uses 3 M3 x 25 screws and one M3 x 22. plus one more screw to attach to the effector. For added insurance, I added a cable tie as can be seen in the first photo.
Designed in Onshape. Inspired by thing# 1600662 by CdeB. For some reason I couldn't list it as a remix.

description.text:
Amazon Echo Wall or Ceiling Mount.

  • Two Piece - Compression Fit - Very Stable and Secure
  • The screw holes are for #8 screws. (Holes: 9mm and 4mm)
    (http://www.homedepot.com/p/The-Hillman-Group-3-8-in-Pop-Toggle-with-Screw-6-Pack-376255/202243047) These work perfect!

Printer Settings:

  • Sliced using Simplify 3D (prints look nicer when sliced using S3D than Cura and Slic3r)
  • PETG at 0.3mm layer height
  • Main Exterior Piece - 70% Infill
  • Secondary Interior Piece - 100% Infill

It doesn't really need sanding, but if your printer is not as accurate, some light sanding will make the fit more snug and even. When installing the two pieces with the echo in place, there will be a little bit of resistance, just pull up on each side until the two back pieces are flush and tight.

You need to determine an angle for a mechanism in rotation ? It's easy to find a sensor who do this function quickly and cheaper, but these products give relative position. However, in some applications, you need to measure an absolute position for an object in rotation. But this kind of sensors (absolute rotary encoder) are expensive and due to high precision mechanism, it is difficult to integrate.
Based on Gray code (a reflected binary code), these sensors use a disc containing several tracks coded in Gray code with an optical bloc to detect the current position.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

I propose you, with this project, to design your own absolute rotary encoder with your favorite 3D printer.
How ? To begin... it's necessary to determine your need in angle precision, you want lot of angle precision ? more tracks are necessary in your disc ! But draw manualy any disc with a gray code of 4 and more is completely crazy !! :)
To help you, I wrote a Blender python script to generate a custom disc with any number of tracks. Warning ! Generate a disc with lot tracks need several minutes of processing ... or a good computer ! :)

Download this script :
gray_generation.py.

By default, the script generate a Gray disc of 4 tracks. To change this, open the script and change the value of "trackCount" (end of the script)...

gray.makeGray(trackCount = 4, startDistance = 1, distance = 0.4)

description.header: Project: SARE sensor (Smart Absolute Rotary Encoder)
description.text:
Project Name

Smart Absolute Rotary Encoder.

Overview & Background

We need to determine a absolute angle , but why use a reflected binary code ? This is simple, a natural binary code is not adapted to detect a change when applied to real physical mecanism, indeed more than one bit can differ during a state transition and there is an important risk to probe an transitional state (wrong state).

Wikipedia - Gray code.

In pratice, an emitter produces an IR light, this light is (or not) masked by this associated track and an IR receiver detect this state to generate a logical binary state. With several tracks, we can determine the current disc position.

To illustrate an interesting use for this kind of sensor, I chose to design a wind direction sensor.
It is designed with a disc of 4 tracks to have 16 positions, we obtain 22.5° of precision for the wind direction.

Here is an example of this sensor connected to an Arduino to control infrared emitters and read infrared receivers.

Objectives

  • Learn the natural binary code and discover an other binary code : the reflected.
  • Learn to use a 3D printer to create a sensor composed of several parts.
  • Learn to use infrared LED emitters en receivers.

Audiences

Due to the complexity of understanding the interest to use the reflected binary code and to print all parts of this sensor, this project is (I think) adapted to 14-15 years old students.

Subjects

Computer science
Mecanic
Optics
Geometry
Engineering
Electronics

Skills Learned (Standards)

Computer science: The binary code
Mecanic: Multi-parts assembly and different types of mecanical linking.
Optics: Using of infrared light.
Geometry: Apply a Gray code to a disc.
Engineering: The interest of relative or absolute rotary sensor.
Electronics: Determine the current angle with an Arduino.

Lesson/Activity

  • Learn the reflected binary code and compare it with natural binary code.
  • Generate your own Gray disc with Blender script.
  • Prepare all parts of wind sensor for 3D printing.
  • Assemble the wind sensor with infrared emitters/receivers.
  • Connect emitters/receivers to an Arduino to detect the current angle position.

Duration

Explain the natural/reflected binary code : 2 hours.
Generate Gray disc: Depending on the number of tracks (1 minute - 1 hour).
Prepare all parts of wind sensor : 4 hours.
Printing : 7-8 hours :
Assemble the wind sensor : 1 hour.
Connect emitters/receivers to an Arduino and write a program: 4 hours

Preparation

Material:

  • Computer with Blender software.
  • 4 Infrared LEDS emitters (in 3 mm) with 4 supports.
  • 4 Infrared receivers (in 3 mm) with 4 supports).
  • Electric wire.
  • An Arduino.

Knowledges:

  • Some bases in geometry and mecanical.

References

Wikipedia - Binary number.
Wikipedia - Gray code.
Wikipedia - Wind direction.
Wikipedia - Infrared.
Wikipedia - Arduino.

General principle Middle support (for infrared receivers) Bottom support (for general structure) Assembly: Middle support insered in the bottom suppor et add the bottom axis Assembly: How the disc is fixed by 2 axis Top support (Emitters support + collimating) Add emitters LED supports, LED, collimating plate, top axis A new version for the top support... better !! :) to test...

title: Low Poly Pikachu Stein (Pikastein)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by a Tweet from @PrintedSolid. A failed giant size Pikachu inspired the Pikachug.
My thought was, "Pikachu could still use a head". The tail is a great idea for a handle but the ears keep you from drinking out the top. Now, why not a stein. This will lift the head out of the way as needed.

I haven't printed this yet, but will when I get a chance to. I made a couple renders to show how the final product is supposed to work.

The hinge bolt is in 2 pieces. You'll need to put the female end through the hinge and glue the male end in place.

I'm not sure what the safest way to treat your print for food safety. Using ABS plastic you could make it water tight giving it an acetone vapor bath.

Alternatively, you can smooth the surface in what ever way you like. Then use a food safe silicone mold to make your final stein.

Using Blender, I took the Low-Poly Pikachu by FLOWALISTIK as my base model. I noticed the "faces" were facing the wrong way, so that needed to be fixed before starting.

First I duplicated the model.
I removed the vertices of the head of one model and all vertices below the neck of the other.
I needed to reshape the tail to work better as a handle so I moved it out and thinned it down a bit. It also needed to be attached to the body.
The hinge took the longest to figure out. After deciding where the best place for it, I needed to model the tip of the tail to work as a thumb handle and allow the lid to open up far enough to drink from.

I finaly found time to build my own Photon Printer (great design by the way :))
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902826

During the build i encountered some smaller problems and made some replacement parts and additional items.

I couldn get the corflute so i designed a cover to print together with some attachments like handle, connector etc.
It should be easy to adjust it to your specific dimensions. Just scale the y-axis in your slicing software.

To fit my laser driver and control into the case i couldnt put the switch into the left side, so i made a simple cover. As i'm powering the driver with 12v i don't need the plug for the arduino, so to avoid putting the plug into the wrong socket i made a cover for the ardiono socket as well.

My DVD carriage is lying deep between the two rods, so a plate for covering the distance helps leveling the working plate.

For easy fixing and aligning of the blank material i made a magnetic bracket system.

With these parts the Photon Printer working fine and easy to handle.

description.text:
The inherent floppiness of the Prusa frame annoys everyone. Here's my attempt at fixing it. This thing keeps the same rod spacing, though you will gain a little Z height and Y travel at the expense of some X clearance, if the nuts are right at the end of your rods. Also, this thing can produce accurate copies of the Huxley vertex (by editing the scad file), which is not available in openscad format, I believe. Which also inspired me to make this, as I think they look cool. Detailed description
I've been wanting to stiffen up the Prusa frame for a while, as my intention is to have a removable carriage for light milling http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11535 . This thread http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?151,112816 (you'll need to manually copy and paste the whole address, thingiverse's new style can't cope) got me thinking about how to stiffen up the Prusa frame. One thing I never understood is why the triangular section of the frame gets the widest part of the vertex, despite a triangle being inherently strong, leaving the narrow part of the vertex to give strength to the square part of the frame, which has to resist the forces of the X-axis moving around. The Mendel had much wider frame vertices, and it feels like the Prusa's are slimmed down too much. So I have designed these vertices to have the strength the other way around, to hopefully support the weaker square part of the frame. And if that doesn't work, there is also a captive nut space in each foot for bracing the frame. Bracing can be done in one of two ways:

  • Use a square MDF / Plywood / Alumin(i)um sheet with an appropriate cutout, sort of like one side of a Ultimaker/Makerbot, to make the frame rigid without compromising build volume.

  • Attach a cross-brace of M8 studding (connector to come). I know, I know, you'll probably scream and shout that this will reduce build volume. And it's true, it will, but not that much. Most things I build seem to be short, so I value stiffness. I also have a long-held ambition to use the frame for milling, so need greater stiffness. But then the bars are easily removable too.
    • You can also use captive nuts in the vertices' feet to bolt your Prusa to a board. Feel free to edit the openscad script and come up with vertex dimensions that you feel will improve rigidity. Build volume of the 1-footed vertex is about the same as the standard Prusa footed vertices. The 2-footed vertex is a bit more. I have printed out this thing now, and even without the cross-brace, I would say that the frame was more resilient to flexing and high-speed oscillation. With the cross-brace, which is easily removed, movement is completely eliminated. The heated bed still has full range of movement. The brace is offset away from the build area, but does cut into it, so careful arrangement of tall parts is needed. Questions, observations, comments and/or suggestions all gratefully received.

Before printing, check that you can print out the stls to the tolerances - I have set the M8 holes to 8.2mm. I prefer a tight fit, rather than have rods flopping about. Also, all settings are editable in the scad file, if you'd prefer to have the vertex wider/narrower.
  • Print out 4x of the 1-footed and 2x of the 2-footed vertex, and 2x .
  • Disassemble your machine (I know, I know...)
  • Put M4 nuts/nylocs in the nut traps BEFORE putting the frame together. Put the nut in the outer M8 rod hole, and thread a bolt into it from the foot end to pull it into the trap. Obviously this is going to be stuck in there once the frame is back together, which could be annoying. Still, it looks nice and neat!
    • 4a. If you are going to brace one side of your printer with sheet material, contruct the frame with the 2-footed vertex at the bottom on the same side, and 2 of the 1-footed vertices at the top of the frame pointing out the same side. The last 2 1-footed vertices go on the other side, feet down. You will have four attaching points for your sheet. Cut a hole out of it to allow for print bed/part clearance. 4b. If you are going to use a cross-brace, put a 1-footed vertex at the top of the frame pointing one way, and one pointing the other. At the bottom of the frame, put a 2-footed vertex on the opposite corner. Once assembled, fit cross-braces.
  • Enjoy solid, fast printing, once you've got the rest of your frame back together.

comments.text: what version are you using my z motors are on top.
comments.author: jjhcs1

comments.text: Did you come up with the inverted z idea?Â  I have not seen that.Â  Does it help something by itself?
comments.author: Creatorson

comments.text: Well, the original Mendel had the Z motor at the bottom, though there was only one and it had a belt to turn the other side. Also, plenty of other machines have their motors at the bottom, so no, it wasn't an original idea. My reason for doing it was that I felt there was less chance of the z-couplers slipping, and that all my wiring was at the bottom as I don't like the build area obscured by electronics (makes it hard to get at the extruder), so wiring everything at the bottom was easier. It's been perfectly reliable, and now every new machine seems to have them at the bottom; Printrbot, Mendel90, Prusa3.
comments.author: Creatorson

description.text:
Found this awesome Luger at
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/p08-luger-functional-assembly-5545
and the MP40 at
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1038339 or https://www.myminifactory.com/object/mp40-23568
https://youtu.be/IvAqvsSKfNc
I spent a week remixing these files to fit beautifully on a 200x 200 bed using ABS
Uses 190gms of ABS plastic and about 9.5hrs to print just the Luger Parts 1 assembly. The other two files about 5 hours each
The MP40 used 960gms of ABS Plastic and took just over 40hrs to print
The prints came out perfectly as a full reproduction replica.
All credit to the designer Daniel Lillygreen
My boys are loving playing world war games in the back yard with these models ; )
RobV local Rolleston talent sculpted and painted and added additional working parts to turn the darker blue of the two Lugers into an exceptional authentic looking piece.
Note this is not a working gun. Just a replica model!

https://www.thingiverse.com/EDN3RD/makes Ednerd came up with an awesome way of making the Lugers cocking handle cock back like the original. Check out the pics in the thing files of his idea, Questions I guess about the idea can be directed to him, Cheers Jace

comments.author: HappyGavGav

comments.text:
Hi Gav, yes .2mm layer height will be fine. PLA & ABS will both work fine also but both have there pros and cons.
I find ABS stronger, easier to sand and a breeze to glue together with acetone.
ABS can be difficult to print and is susceptible to warping with out the right adhesion and requires a good hot-end and heater bed

author: juanpis

description.text: Students will discuss designs to help Goldilocks rebuild chairs for the three bears

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

After reading the story Goldilocks and the Three Bears, your students will have the task to design a chair for one of the three bears. The chair may be made fully printed, partially printed or of found objects. Objectives
Through this lesson, students will learn which designs hold the most weight and think through how to make the chair large enough for the given bear. Skills Learned (Standards)
  • Use materials to design a device that solves a specific problem or a solution to a specific problem. (1-LS1-1)
  • Make observations (firsthand or from media) to collect data that can be used to make comparisons. (1-ESS1-2)
  • K-2-ETS1-2. Develop a simple sketch, drawing, or physical model to illustrate how the shape of an object helps it function as needed to solve a given problem.
  • K-2-ETS1-3. Analyze data from tests of two objects designed to solve the same problem to compare the strengths and weaknesses of how each performs.

Read and Discuss the book Goldilocks and the Three Bears. Talk about the 3 bears and what each would look like. What makes them different/the same. Get out small weights and discuss how much students think each of the bears would weigh. **For this I had weights we used in science class with a pan balance. I also pulled out three stuffed animals, one small, one medium and one large. After “deciding” how heavy each bear would be, I strapped the weights on the animal like a life vest using masking tape. Students then were asked to, in partners, design a chair to hold one of the three bears- not only the size of their rump, but also their weight. (We used 8oz for Baby, 1lb for Momma and 1lb 8oz for Papa.) During the design process you may need to review with students about millimeters, how big the bear is (again in millimeters) After designs are complete, test out the chairs. Place the designated bear on the chair.
  • Is it able to sit without assistance?
  • Count to 30. Does the chair hold the bear?
    • After all chairs are tested, have a discussion.
  • Place successful chairs together. Do they have anything in common? Is there something that all successful chair designers did?
    • Have students write about their experience and how successful their design was. Is there something you wish you would have done differently? Is there something you would like to change on your design but couldn’t figure out how to make it work?
1-2 weeks
Depending on which manner the students want to use to construct the chair, students may need access to: ipads, computer, printer, found objects, glue, etc.

• Show Goldilocks being read https://youtu.be/BVggRyq3LIg
  • Extension: Can you make a chair that is scalable so that it works for each bear?
  • Extension: Is there a physical aspect of your chair that you can change to make it hold more weight or hold a different bear?
  • Extension: Can your baby bear chair still hold Goldilocks?

A camera dolly and rail system that can support a dSLR or other video gear. The system uses 608 series "skateboard" ball bearings and standard hardware found at any home improvement store.

Rails and legs can be made out of any 1" OD tubing or pipe (3/4" steel EMT is cheap and works well).

Update Aug 16: Added motor mount and refined the overall design to improve fit for 3/4" EMT (previous version was too loose).

Update Aug 21: Added rope pulley (fits 5mm motor shaft) and features on end block for attaching rope. Use this and a motor to pull the carriage along the rails.

Parts List:

1x Carriage
2x End Block
4x End Block Leg Adapter
4x Foot
1x Carriage Motor Mount
1x NEMA 17 Stepper Mount

Optional:

  • Offset Leg Adapter - Replaces standard version and allows adjustable legs (good for uneven surfaces or outdoors)
Hardware Required:

Need to organize some cables around your desk?  Or perhaps your desk has some ill-fitting grommets like mine did.  No problem, just drill a two inch hole using a standard hole cutting saw, print this out, and snap it in place.  
The sleeve seats firmly into the 2" hole, and the cover snaps securely in place and can be rotated after assembly.  
If anybody wants additional sizes let me know, because now that the model is all set up I can bang out alternate diameters no problem.
Update - 1/8/2016... just added the two parts of this thing as separate files, as requested by Suren1987.

I printed this using ABS on a Replicator 2X.  
Settings: 10% infill, 3 shells, 0.2 MM layer height, no raft or supports.

title: Protector for MTR3B Mountain Topper Ham Radio

description.text:
Protector for the switches and face plate on Steve Weber's (KD1JV) amazing MTR3B three band QRP Mountain Topper ham radio now sold by LNR Precision.

On a Yahoo group several people complained about breaking their switches during transport. This protector prevents that. Note that the blocks along the inside ends support it on the black ends of the U shaped base plate. No part touches the radio's blue face plate. If pressure is applied to the middle of the protector, the round pad in the middle takes the load, but it normally doesn't touch the radio's face plate.
Weight is less than 1oz.
I printed it in PLA but consider ABS in case you leave it out in the hot sun during a SOTA activation :-) You may want to adjust the tension of the 2 clip ears by warming them over a candle and bending in slightly.

UPDATE: (8/16/2016) uploaded MTR_3B Mountain Topper Protector_Larger Clips.stl. This has larger ears to grab the bottom of the MTR3B better. They overhang but my ROBO3D prints them OK without any support material in ABS with the fan OFF.

description.text:
This is a easy to print Y axis roller carriage add-in to the stock carriage.
This replaces the upper PTFE slide on the right side with a construction that uses 2 pcs. 625VV (5x16x5 Bearings with a V-groove) and 2 pcs. M3x10 screws. I made this to remove the ability for the carriage to rotate in the right side of the machine. and thereby eliminating skipping in the Y axis whilst providing a way more sturdy construction. This is the first thing i upload to thingiverse... I have made other improvements to my solidoodle 3, of which i will probably upload in the next few days. Hope you like it

I printed it in white ABS with 80% infill also without support.  
You may have to cut a little excess material from the existing carriage to make room for the foremost bearing.  
Also dont mind that the screws might pop out of the top surface when screwing them in.

description.text:
This is an Airbox Vent that you can print at home to increase airflow to your motor. It will accommodate 5/8 thick air filter foam. Cut 1 inch circles out of the foam sheet for a snug fit in the 0.875" barrel, oil them, and pop them into place. They are designed to fit in 1" holes drilled into your airbox lid or sides. The fit should be snug to prevent particulate from making it past these mini-filters. I also suggest adding a thin bead of silicone to the mating flange to ensure a good seal to the airbox or lid. These increase the amount of airflow to your airbox, and allow your engine to breathe more freely, allowing for faster acceleration on your motorcycle, ATV, dirtbike, or whatever it may be.

description.text: This is a small box that comes in two parts. I designed it to hold a ring, but it would be good for other jewelry as well (or whatever you can think of). The two pieces snap together and the result is a functioning lid.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

High
The print comes in two pieces that must be snapped together once complete. There are two nobs that fit into two holes at the rear of the design.
TinkerCAD https://tinkercad.com/things/aZ2hfq641d2
Credit to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:417414, I just added a couple of things to it. Looks really cool!

I found this component tester on ebay for about $13, so I came here hoping to find an enclosure to print to put it in. There are a few other boxes to print, but none for the EZM328 (at least last I checked a few days ago). So now there is.

Yes, I know, there are some issues with my print. I'm working that out.

The first print I did didn't fit, so I redrew it. It now fits, but I forgot the numbers. The file I loaded here has the numbers on it. I included a picture of the bad print so you can see what the numbers will look like on yours. I'm not going to reprint mine just for the numbers. I'll just put a sticker on it or something.

I'm sure there are better ways I could have designed this, but it works. The back edge of the circuit board fits into a channel in the box base. You then put a screw into the forward left corner. Then put the top on and install three screws in the bottom and one screw on the top that will go through the right hand corner and into the base. Eventually I will put some rubber feet on the bottom. There were only two available screw holes in the circuit board, so this is what I came up with. Feel free to change it if you want. For screw, I just used whatever scavenged screws I had.

Any normal print settings should work, but the top will need support.

description.text:
This is the open source printable version of the back plate for the Rigidbot electronics upgrade kit.

It is split in two pieces so that it can be printed on the 10 x 10 bed of a Rigidbot regular for its own upgrade or on a Rigidbot2.

The upgrade kit consists of the Left and Right Back Plate pieces, the Anchor pieces (print 2) that are inserted in the corner knuckle where the lower bar is removed, and the Foot Risers (print 4). In this printable version of the back plate the mounting frame for the main board is integrated into the back panel.

Note: more details of the electronics upgrade kit this back plate is part of can be viewed here: https://plus.google.com/113930448883604105560/posts/NF4w4YeCzUF

As part of the upgrade process I would suggest that the quick release spool holders be printed with the other parts. They are found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687553

The parts are Cura scaled and oriented for printing.

These parts require the use of calibrated filament in order to fit properly. I used the following pieces to do the calibrations on the filament used. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

Printer:

Rigidbot 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Remove old tape and clean the bed with Windex before applying new tape. This will keep the parts from pulling up and warping.

To get a strong part use at least a .8mm wall thickness for the sides and top and bottom. Be patient. This is a long print but it comes out very strong and rigid.

Removing parts from bed

It helps to heat the bed to 50C when prying the parts off the bed. Run a thin blade under all the edges. Use a larger flat blade for the middle sections. A thin putty knife is very handy for this.

Edit: A 3/4" chisel with the bevel side down works really well and doesn't damage the tape. Pry up at one or two spots and the part pops right off. Heating the bed back up seems to be optional with this tool.

description.text:
Another cool model found here
https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/search.html?q=T800&backendClass=entity

This is a 4 compartment storage system. It is large enough for many of your small screws and small parts.

I designed it with 123D Design and the parts files are also here. Feel free to modify it.

I've removed the box with the legs. I could not get it to print properly. However, the box without the legs seems to print fine. I'm leaving the 123D Design files if someone wants to play with this.

All of the files appear to be the correct size. The box and drawers fit together perfectly. The only problem that I ran into with printing the box is the long print time, and issues related to that print time. The box takes 20 hours to print on my printer. 2 drawers being printed at the same time takes just over 4 hour on my printer. But I have my printer slowed down for other reasons. Plus the drawers have thin sides.

Just a simple radially symmetrical ornament I made for my desk: more to practice with blender than for any actual purpose!  
Any problems, just give me a shout in the comments and I'll get onto it ASAP  
There are four different patterns included: Quad, cubic, and quad angle; and one additional "crystal" that I'm still working on.

Quad - basic design
Quad angle - expanded version of the basic deisign
Quad cubic - cubic version of quad angle
Quad angle doubled - a large crystalline version of quad angle: good luck printing it (I was having trouble getting it to connect to the supports in repetier-host/slic3r - I'll add them manually I think xD) You can also just glue two "quad angles" together for the exactly same effect... it just means the seam will be visible (unless you sand and/or putty it ;))
A radiused sanding block for shaping a guitar fretboard.

Simply stick sandpaper to the surface and use it to sand the fretboard blank.  
Three sizes included which correspond to the fretboard radii used by Martin, Taylor and Gibson (according to the internet). The OpenSCAD file is also available if you want to make a custom size or radius.

description.text: This is model of one of the thoracic (chest) vertebrae of a goat. The vertebrae were scanned in a medical CT scanner (GE 16-slice scanner) and processed in various radiology and 3D modeling programs. I added a loop on the top of the vertebra of this model so that it could be used as a pendant. In the photos showing sterling silver and bronze models, I drilled a small hole in the vertebra for stringing. This model is a part of my collection of animal skulls and bones featured in my new Kickstarter project. Please visit the project at http://kck.st/19uUDNC

title: MP Select Mini Side Cooling Panel Mod

description.text:
This is a replacement side panel for the Monoprice Select Mini (Malyan M200) 3D printer. This is particularly useful for those who operate in high ambient temperatures, those who keep their printer in an enclosure for ABS printing or anyone who has added a compact power supply inside the main housing to replace the external one. If none of those conditions apply for you, this is probably overkill...but it looks cool ;-)

For those with only a Select Mini, the panel is printed in two pieces, and held together by dovetail and the fan. For those with access to a larger printer, it can be printed in one piece. In addition, there is a fan grill to protect the blades and your fingers.

Here are two 40x10 fans I would reccomend:
http://amzn.to/2em3zOk

MAJOR UPDATE: There was an error in the USB/SD port locations, apologies to anyone who already made one! ( Thanks to Katostrofik for catching it )

Update 1: Added DWG for anyone who wants to lasercut it

Update 2: Made the Split version easier to print flat on the Mini.

Update 3: Added passive vented version for those who do not want to add fans.
